awd_titl_txt: Laboring for Less? Understanding the Micro-Level Anatomy of the Aggregate Labor Share Decline
awd_abstract_narration:
The term labor share is defined as the share of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) that is paid out to workers as salaries and wages. The labor share of US GDP has declined for several decades; this is also true in many other countries around the world. This research project seeks to understand the causes of this decline and the consequences for the well-being of working Americans. Past research on this topic has focused on documenting aggregate patterns in labor share, at the level of an entire economy, an economic sector, or a specific industry. This investigation will use a different approach, and will study the dynamics of labor share by looking at evidence from a large number of individual factories and retail outlets. The research seeks to distinguish between trends that are common across all these establishments and shifts of economic activity from individual factories and stores with relatively high labor share to low labor share establishments. Initial results suggest that this second kind of shift in economic activity is the major driver of the aggregate pattern. These preliminary results also show that individual establishments only maintain a low labor share for a few years; the team will also test hypotheses about why these establishments have a low share and why that share increases after several years. Understanding the causes of labor share decline is important.  We need this information to better target policies encouraging firms to hire and train the U.S. workforce.

The project will develop new knowledge about the establishment-level factors that are responsible for the aggregate decline in labor share. It will do this by using simple but powerful statistical tools to analyze establishment level data from the U.S. Census of Manufactures and Retail Trade. It will highlight the elements of current economic models that are inconsistent with the data on dynamics at both the establishment and aggregate levels of analysis. The result will be more useful information on establishment-level heterogeneity that can be used to redesign the assumed dynamics of firm behavior in macroeconomic models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

A decline in the share of national income going to labor has been documented in many countries and industries. To further our understanding of the micro-level determinants behind the decline in the aggregate labor share, in Kehrig and Vincent (forthcoming) we focus on the U.S. manufacturing sector. The Census of Manufactures, conducted every five years since 1967, allows us to obtain 1.7 million establishment-year labor share observations, where the labor share of establishment i in year t is defined as:

LS = W*L/VA.

Here, W corresponds to the average compensation per worker (including benefits); L is the number of workers; and VA is value added. Our study documents five salient facts that underline the factors behind the dynamics of the labor share at a more aggregate level.

 

 

Finding #1: Aggregate Decline through Reallocation

 

Between 1967 and 2012, the share of labor in total income for the manufacturing sector declined from about 61 to 41 percent. Yet, over the same time period, the labor share of the median establishment increased by about 4 percentage points. How could this be? The two facts jointly point to a massive reallocation of economic activity towards low labor share establishments, as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1:  lang="EN-CA">Distribution of establishments and value added across labor shares

 

Finding #2: Superstars are ?Rising Stars?

 

What is behind the concentration over time of economic activity towards low labor share establishments? This phenomenon can arise from three scenarios:

1.     Big Player scenario: Large establishments see their labor shares drop (e.g., because of an increase in their profit margins).

2.     Superstar scenario: Superstar establishments gain market share thanks to their high productivity and low labor shares.

3.     Rising Star scenario: Some establishments simultaneously experience a rise in their market shares and fall in their labor shares.

Figures 2 and 3: Counterfactual and actual aggregate labor shares in the "Big Player" and "Superstar" Economies

 

Finding #3: Labor Shares Are Driven by Value Added, Not Wages or Employment

 

Next, we analyze the components of the micro-level labor shares. To simplify the exposition, we focus on low labor share (LL) establishments, defined as those in the bottom quintile of the labor share distribution in a given year. LL establishments are central to the decline of the manufacturing labor share.

First, we show in Figure 3 that the establishments with the lowest labor shares in a given industry and region are characterized by higher labor productivity (VA/L) than their peers, not lower wages (W).

Figure 4: Relative labor productivity and wages across labor shares

Second, we turn our attention to dynamics and ask the following question: how did today?s LL establishments look like in the previous Census? We find that relative to non-LL units, their labor shares fell by 18 percentage points on average over the previous five years. Even more striking is that 17.7 of these percentage points come from a rise in value added, leaving almost no role for wages or employment.

 

Finding #4: Low labor shares are associated with higher prices

Where does the relatively high labor productivity and size of LL establishments come about? For a subset of establishments, products and years, the U.S. Census Bureau provides the physical quantity of products shipped in addition to the value of sales. This allows us to ask: How do low labor share establishments price their products relative to their peers? The answer: LL establishments charge, on average, 21% higher prices for similar products. This evidence is difficult to reconcile with explanations that rely on technology factors as the main drivers of labor share differences.

 

Finally, we document that LL status is very temporary: After having experienced a 18 percentage points drop in its labor share over the five previous years, the typical low labor share establishment sees a more than a 15 ppt increase in the following five years (see the left panel of Figure 4). The fact that low labor shares are on average short-lived is also evident in the yearly data from the Annual Survey of Manufactures (right panel of Figure 4). Moreover, we find that this V-shaped pattern has become more pronounced over time.

 

 

Figures 5 and 6: Labor share dynamics of low labor share establishments

 

 

Concluding remarks

All in all, our body of evidence points to the interaction of volatile demand shocks and a winner-takes-all market structure. This combination favors the rise of shooting stars, corporate champions whose fortunes are fleeting and at the mercy of changing tastes and new competing products. Increased market integration may have exacerbated these forces: globalization has expanded the varieties available to customers, but also the reach of market leaders and the potential set of competitors to replace them.
